column1: #Text=Classic Maya hieroglyphic panel looted from the site of Cancuén , Guatemala sometime before 1981 .

#Text=In 1981 , Nicholas Hellmuth received two small photographs of a Maya hieroglyphic panel from the Guatemalan site of Cancuén This was the last anyone heard of the panel until 1994 when it appeared on the art market .
#Text=In 1995 the New York Times reported that a fifteen minute videotape containing images of the panel was being circulated among art dealers .
#Text=The piece reportedly had a price tag of $ 75,000 USD .
#Text=The panel is extraordinary : 160 glyphs arranged in sixteen columns and ten rows on a slab of limestone 138 cm long and 94 cm wide .

#Text=It was commissioned by lord Taj Chan Ahk , the same ruler depicted on a ballcourt marker from Cancuén ( see Encyclopedia entry on the Cancuén Ballcourt Marker for more information about this object ) , and is a record of more than a century of the late history of the polity .
#Text=It starts mid-sentence and was probably one of a pair of panels , the other of which is now lost .
#Text=Conflicting rumours exist concerning the whereabouts of the lost second panel .
#Text=Some believe it is still buried somewhere at Cancuén or in a private collection somewhere in Guatemala .
#Text=Others report that it may have fallen into the Pasión River during a dispute between looters .
#Text=Citing unnamed local sources , Kistler reports that the known panel was once part of a throne : it formed the back of the thrown and the lost panel formed the seat .

#Text=Warning that her information is not verifiable , Kistler relates that a canoe carrying both pieces capsized and , because the seat of the throne was the heavier of the two pieces , it sank to the bottom of the river and could not be recovered .

#Text=Kistler believes that the two panels were looted sometime during Guatemala ’ s 35-year civil war by members of the military and that the surviving panel was hidden until 1994 , when it was offered for sale .
#Text=She notes that military and guerrilla troops were operating in the deep jungle at that time and would have had access to various archaeological sites .
#Text=As of 2004 , the panel was in a private collection and was being displayed in the Museo El Príncipe Maya , a private museum in Cobán , Guatemala .
#Text=The owner of the piece and the details of the sale in which it was acquired are not publicly known .
